title: 106_hr2661
content: The Act titled "American Indian Education Foundation Act of 1999" is added to the United States Code, establishing the American Indian Education Foundation. The American Indian Education Foundation is a federally chartered corporation with perpetual existence, incorporated in the District of Columbia. It is a charitable and nonprofit organization, not an agency of the United States. The American Indian Education Foundation encourages private gifts for the benefit of the Office of Indian Education Programs. It supports educational opportunities for American Indians attending Bureau funded schools. The American Indian Education Foundation supports educational opportunities for American Indians attending Bureau funded schools through private gifts and assistance to government agencies. The foundation's governing body, the board of directors, oversees its operations with at least 11 members as outlined in its constitution and bylaws. The board of the American Indian Education Foundation consists of at least 11 members, including the Secretary of the Interior and the Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs as ex officio nonvoting members. Board members must be U.S. citizens knowledgeable in American Indian education and represent diverse viewpoints. The officers of the foundation include a secretary elected from among the board members. The officers of the American Indian Education Foundation, as outlined in the constitution and bylaws, include a secretary who serves as the chief operating officer. Board members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The foundation has the power to adopt and amend its constitution and bylaws for property management and regulation. The American Indian Education Foundation has the power to adopt and amend its constitution and bylaws, acquire, own, lease, encumber, and transfer property, sue and be sued, and perform acts necessary to carry out its purposes. The foundation's principal office is in the District of Columbia, but activities can be conducted throughout the United States. The foundation must comply with laws on service of process. The American Indian Education Foundation must comply with laws on service of process in each State where it operates. The foundation is liable for the acts of its officers and agents within their authority, with board members personally liable for gross negligence. Administrative costs cannot exceed 10% of funds transferred and donations received in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary of the Interior appoints initial voting members of the board of directors within 6 months of enactment. Subsequent boards must conform to the constitution and bylaws of the American Indian Education Foundation. During the 5-year period after enactment, the Secretary of the Interior can provide support to the foundation, including personnel, facilities, and funds for board member travel expenses. Reimbursements are required from the foundation for services and funds provided. The Secretary of the Interior can continue providing facilities and support services to the foundation on a reimbursable cost basis after the initial 5-year period. Reimbursements for services and travel expenses will be deposited in the Treasury.
